info.name: PACKAGE MGR => STAGING - TM Denver - Aurora Highlands Horizon - Canvas - 22C1-Celeste
info.description: # Introduction This collection provides a set of HTTP request examples for managing packages with our visualization vendor, Aareas Interactive, through their API. It demonstrates each of the four CRUD operations—Create, Read, Update, and Delete—using the corresponding API endpoints. Each request type performs one of these operations against the Aareas Interactive service, making it easy to integrate package management into your workflow. There are 4 types of HTTP requests. Each of them allows us to interact with the packages we have defined with Aareas Interactive. - **GET** requests retrieve one or more packages. - **POST** requests create new packages. - **PUT** requests update existing packages. - **DELETE** requests remove packages. # APIs & Request Response Cycles An **API** (Application Programming Interface) is like a waiter in a restaurant: it’s the “middleman” that takes your request, tells the kitchen (another piece of software) what you want, and then brings back the result. For someone just starting out, the key things to know are: - **What an API is** - A defined set of rules (endpoints, methods, data formats) that one program exposes so that other programs can interact with it. - Think of it as a standardized “menu” of actions you can ask the software to perform. - **What an API does** 1. **Accepts Requests**: You send a request (e.g., “Get all packages”). 2. **Processes Requests**: The API’s backend figures out how to fetch or compute the data. 3. **Returns Responses**: You get back the data or confirmation (e.g., a lsit of packages in JSON). There are several important parts to sending an HTTP request: **The type of request**: Is the request a GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE (Read/Retrieve, Create, Update, Delete)? **Where to send it:** The URL tells Postman where to send the request via an address, similar to how the US Postal Service uses addresses to pinpoint locations to which to deliver physical packages. It contains a signature the tells Postman a server and specific endpoint (a destination for HTTP requests) where the request is to be delivered. **What additional information to include in the request**: The request can also contain additional information to transmit to the endpoint. This can be in the form of _**parameters**_ or a _**request body**_. **GET and DELETE requests do not usually have a body** and sending one is usually not standard practice. Here is an example of a route parameter that tells the endpoint more about what you want to receive in the response. Each request in the collection includes a documentation section where you can learn more about the route parameters you can change to achieve the desired response to your request. It is best to read it and fully acquaint yourself with how each request works before sending one. **Most POST or PUT requests, that add or update data, will include a body.** The body is in a format known as JSON (JavaScript Object Notation). Here is an example of a request body included with a POST request. JSON is used to transmit data between diverse technical systems using a common language. Unlike the name implies, it can be read and parsed by many programming languages, not just JavaScript. In order to make sure we are sending request bodies that the responding API can read and understand, we must make sure that we follow the rules for JavaScript formatting. Let's dive deeper into some specific syntax rules you'll need to follow to write correct JSON request bodies. # JSON Quick Start Guide ### Basic Building Blocks ##### Objects One building block used in JSON is called an object. Objects contain zero or more key/value pairs, separated by commas. Additionally... - **Objects are surrouneded by curly braces** **`{ }`** defining their beginning and end, and can be nested inside other objects. In this example, a single object makes up the JSON request body, as is the case with ALL request bodies. Additionally, `productGUIDs`, an array that is a property of the main request object, contains 3 additional objects. - **Keys must be surrounded by double-quotes (quotation marks).** Single-quotes (aka. apostrophes) are NOT allowed in valid JSON formatting. - **Values can be one of the following types:** string, number, object, array, boolean, or null. - **Key/value pairs are separated by commas,** with no comma following the last pair. Below is one example of a key (called "productGUID") and a string value of a globally- unique identifier (or GUID). Note that the main request object also contains a key called "productGUIDs", with an array value containing 3 objects. ##### Arrays An array can be used to represent a list of items, like objects or primitives (simple data types like string, number, etc.). An array can also be empty, if no items are in the list. An array... - **is enclosed in square brackets** `[ ]` defining its beginning and end. - **has items separated by commas,** with no comma following the last item. ### Data Types for Values | Type | Format example | | --- | --- | | String | `"hello world"` | | Number | `42`, `3.14`, `-7` | | Object | `{ "key": "value" }` | | Array | `[1, 2, 3]` | | Boolean | `true`, `false` | | Null | `null` | - **Strings** must be in double quotes and may include escape sequences (`\"`, `\\`, `\n`, etc.). - **Numbers** have no quotes: no leading zeros, no `+` sign. - **Booleans** and **null** are literal keywords, all lowercase. ### Whitespace and Formatting JSON ignores whitespace (spaces and newline/return characters) outside of strings. However, careful use of line breaks and indentation can dramatically improve the readability of your JSON text. Line breaks can serve as visual dividers between items in an array, or key/value pairs in an object. ### Comments in JSON While strict JSON does not support comments, you can still use them in constructing your request bodies to add clarity and readability, as well as making your JSON more maintainable when it comes to long request bodies with otherwise nondescript groups of items. Many tools and editors accept “JSON with Comments” (often called **JSONC**) or **JSON5**, which allow... - **Single-line comments** with `//` - **Multi-line comments** with `/\* … \*/` Notice the clarity provided by the comments shown here. Visual Studio Code is one editor that allows you to build files of .jsonc type, which will provide syntax highlighting to help identify errors as they occur, allowing for immediate correction, as well as comments. It is highly recommended that you edit request bodies in an advanced text editor like Visual Studio code, in order to take advantage of these additional tools, and past the bodies into the request in Postman prior to sending. To download Visual Studio Code, click [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/download). Be aware that, although comments can be used in request bodies sent to an endpoint, the response likely will not contain comments. Therefore, they are largely a tools to provide the additional contruction and maintenance benefits described earlier. ### Common Gotchas There are a common mistakes that can cause your JSON to be unreadable by the responding system. - **Trailing commas**. This is when you include a comma following the last key/value pair in an object, or the last item in an array. - **Unquoted keys**. Keys in a key/value pair MUST be surrounded with double quotes. - **Single quotes**. Single quotes are not allowed for keys or string values in JSON. - **Unclosed objects or arrays**. Objects must start and end with curly braces `{ }` , while arrays must start and end with square brackets `[ ]` . Forgetting to end your object or array appropriately will cause problems with your JSON formatting and validity. If you are unsure of whether or not your JSON is 100% valid and correct, you may want to use an online JSON validator, like [JSON Checker](https://jsonchecker.com/) to double check. Since JSON validators are great at determining if there are erros, but not so great at pointing out what or where they are, AI tools, like [ChatGPT](https://chat.openai.com/) can also be prompted to point out specific errors in your JSON request body, if you suspect that is the cause of a failing request, and sometimes even correct them. _**Use these AI tools with caution, however, making sure they don't change the substance of the data in the JSON.**_ #### With these basic rules, you’ll be able to write, read, and validate JSON confidently!

item.name: Example Requests

request.description:
## Get Client Product Package List

This endpoint retrieves a list of all client product packages based on the provided parameters.

### HTTP Method

`GET`

### Endpoint

`https://apirc.aareas.com/api/ClientProduct/GetClientProductPackageList/{`**`visualizableOnly`**`}/{accountName}/{clientID}`

#### Parameter end users can change:

- **visualizableOnly**(true/false): Indicates whether to return renderable (visualizable) IDs only. Set to false to return all IDs regardless.
    

#### Parameter end users should not change (internal to Aareas):

- `accountName` (string): The name of the client for whom the product packages are being retrieved.
    
- `clientID` (string): The unique identifier for the client.
    

### Expected Response

The response will be in JSON format and will contain the following structure:

``` json
{
  "responseObject": [
    {
      "packageName": "string", // Name of the package
      "packageGUID": "string", // Unique identifier for the package
      "productGUIDs": [
        {
          "surface": "string", // Surface name
          "productGUID": "string" // Unique identifier for the product
        }
      ],
      "discontinued": boolean, // Indicates if the package is discontinued
      "hidden": boolean // Indicates if the package is hidden
    }
  ],
  "responseMessage": "string", // Message related to the response
  "responseType": integer, // Type of the response
  "responseStatus": integer // Status of the response
}

 ```

### Response Codes

- `200 OK`: The request was successful, and the response contains the requested data.

## Get Single Package Detail

This endpoint retrieves the details of a specific client package based on the provided package identifier.

### Request

- **Method**: GET
    
- **URL**: `https://apirc.aareas.com/api/ClientProduct/GetClientPackage/{`**`packageId`**`}/{accountName}/{clientId}`
    

#### Parameter end users can change:

- **`packageId`** (string): The unique identifier for the package you want to retrieve.
    

#### Parameter end users should not change (internal to Aareas):

- `accountName` (string): The name of the client for whom the product packages are being retrieved.
    
- `clientID` (string): The unique identifier for the client.
    

### Response

The response is returned in JSON format and contains the following structure:

- **responseObject** (object): Contains the details of the client package.
    
    - **packageName** (string): The name of the package (may be empty).
        
    - **packageGUID** (string): The unique identifier for the package (may be empty).
        
    - **productGUIDs** (array): A list of products associated with the package.
        
        - Each product object contains:
            
            - **surface** (string): The surface type of the product (may be empty).
                
            - **productGUID** (string): The unique identifier for the product (may be empty).
                
    - **discontinued** (boolean): Indicates whether the package is discontinued.
        
    - **hidden** (boolean): Indicates whether the package is hidden.
        
- **responseMessage** (string): A message providing additional context about the response (may be empty).
    
- **responseType** (integer): A code representing the type of response.
    
- **responseStatus** (integer): A code representing the status of the response.
    

### Example Response

``` json
{
  "responseObject": {
    "packageName": "",
    "packageGUID": "",
    "productGUIDs": [
      {
        "surface": "",
        "productGUID": ""
      }
    ],
    "discontinued": true,
    "hidden": true
  },
  "responseMessage": "",
  "responseType": 0,
  "responseStatus": 0
}

 ```

## Add Client Packages This endpoint allows users to add a new package to the system. ### Request - **Method:** POST - **URL:** `https://apirc.aareas.com/api/ClientProduct/AddClientPackages/{accountName}/{clientID}` #### Request Body The request body must be in JSON format and should include the following fields: - **packageName** (string): The name of the package being added. - **packageGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the package. - **productGUIDs** (array of objects): A list of products associated with the package and surfaces to apply them to. Each object in the array should contain: - **surface** (string): The name of the surface. - **productGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the product. - **discontinued** (boolean): Indicates whether the package is discontinued. - **hidden** (boolean): Indicates whether the package is hidden from the client view. #### Example Request Body ``` json { "packageName": "Premium Flooring Package 4", "packageGUID": "aa52422b-7449-4c16-a228-3c435d...", "productGUIDs": [ { "surface": "Kitchen_Countertop", "productGUID": "348a14de-c285-4c19-8a82-2f31a4..." } ], "discontinued": false, "hidden": false } ``` ### Response The response from the server will confirm the successful addition of the client package. It typically includes a status message and may provide additional details about the created package, such as its GUID and any other relevant information. #### Expected Response Structure

## Update Client Packages This endpoint allows users to update an existing package in the system. ### HTTP Method `GET` ### Endpoint `https://apirc.aareas.com/api/ClientProduct/UpdateClientPackages/{accountName}/{clientID}` #### Parameter end users should not change (internal to Aareas): - `accountName` (string): The name of the client for whom the product packages are being retrieved. - `clientID` (string): The unique identifier for the client. ### Request Body The request body should be in JSON format and include the following parameters: - **packageGUID** (string): The unique identifier for the package to be updated. - **productGUIDs** (array of objects): A list of products associated with the package and surfaces to apply them to. Each object in the array should contain: - **surface** (string): The name of the surface. - **productGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the product. ### Expected Response Format The response will typically include a confirmation of the update status and may contain additional information regarding the updated packages. The exact structure of the response will depend on the implementation. Ensure that you provide valid GUIDs for both the package and products to successfully update the client packages.

## Delete Client Packages

This endpoint allows the user to delete client packages associated with a specific client ID and package ID. It is primarily used to manage and remove unwanted or outdated packages from a client's account.

### Request

- **Method**: `GET`
    
- **URL**: `https://apirc.aareas.com/api/ClientProduct/DeleteClientPackages/{`**`packageId`**`}/{accountName}/{clientID}`
    

#### Parameter end users can change:

- **`packageId`** (string): The unique identifier for the package you want to retrieve.
    

#### Parameter end users should not change (internal to Aareas):

- `accountName` (string): The name of the client for whom the product packages are being retrieved.
    
- `clientID` (string): The unique identifier for the client.
    

### Response

The response will provide confirmation of the deletion action. The structure of the response body typically includes:

- `success` (boolean): Indicates whether the deletion was successful.
    
- `message` (string): A message providing additional information about the result of the deletion request.
    

### Example Response

``` json
{
  "responseObject": "aa52422b-7449-4c16-a228-3c435d40c4d1",
   "responseMessage": "Packages not find",
   "responseType": 1,
   "responseStatus": 1
}

 ```

item.description: These requests show examples of how to utilize each Aareas Interactive endpoint for managing packages. See the documentation for each one for a deep dive into its inner workings.

item.name: TM Canvas - Whole House Collections - POST (Add)

request.description: ## Add Client Packages This endpoint allows users to add a new package to the system. ### Request - **Method:** POST - **URL:** `https://apirc.aareas.com/api/ClientProduct/AddClientPackages/{accountName}/{clientID}` #### Request Body The request body must be in JSON format and should include the following fields: - **packageName** (string): The name of the package being added. - **packageGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the package. - **productGUIDs** (array of objects): A list of products associated with the package and surfaces to apply them to. Each object in the array should contain: - **surface** (string): The name of the surface. - **productGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the product. - **discontinued** (boolean): Indicates whether the package is discontinued. - **hidden** (boolean): Indicates whether the package is hidden from the client view. #### Example Request Body ``` json { "packageName": "Premium Flooring Package 4", "packageGUID": "aa52422b-7449-4c16-a228-3c435d...", "productGUIDs": [ { "surface": "Kitchen_Countertop", "productGUID": "348a14de-c285-4c19-8a82-2f31a4..." } ], "discontinued": false, "hidden": false } ``` ### Response The response from the server will confirm the successful addition of the client package. It typically includes a status message and may provide additional details about the created package, such as its GUID and any other relevant information. #### Expected Response Structure

item.name: POST (Add) - TM Denver - Built-In I Appliance Package - GE Profile - APKPBI10001

request.description: ## Add Client Packages This endpoint allows users to add a new package to the system. ### Request - **Method:** POST - **URL:** `https://apirc.aareas.com/api/ClientProduct/AddClientPackages/{accountName}/{clientID}` #### Request Body The request body must be in JSON format and should include the following fields: - **packageName** (string): The name of the package being added. - **packageGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the package. - **productGUIDs** (array of objects): A list of products associated with the package and surfaces to apply them to. Each object in the array should contain: - **surface** (string): The name of the surface. - **productGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the product. - **discontinued** (boolean): Indicates whether the package is discontinued. - **hidden** (boolean): Indicates whether the package is hidden from the client view. #### Example Request Body ``` json { "packageName": "Premium Flooring Package 4", "packageGUID": "aa52422b-7449-4c16-a228-3c435d...", "productGUIDs": [ { "surface": "Kitchen_Countertop", "productGUID": "348a14de-c285-4c19-8a82-2f31a4..." } ], "discontinued": false, "hidden": false } ``` ### Response The response from the server will confirm the successful addition of the client package. It typically includes a status message and may provide additional details about the created package, such as its GUID and any other relevant information. #### Expected Response Structure

item.name: PUT (Update) - TM Denver - Built-In I Appliance Package - GE Profile - APKPBI10001

request.description: ## Update Client Packages This endpoint allows users to add a new package to the system. ### Request - **Method:** POST - **URL:** `https://apirc.aareas.com/api/ClientProduct/AddClientPackages/{accountName}/{clientID}` #### Request Body The request body must be in JSON format and should include the following fields: - **packageGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the package. - **productGUIDs** (array of objects): A list of products associated with the package and surfaces to apply them to. Each object in the array should contain: - **surface** (string): The name of the surface. - **productGUID** (string): A unique identifier for the product. #### Example Request Body ``` json { "packageName": "Premium Flooring Package 4", "packageGUID": "aa52422b-7449-4c16-a228-3c435d...", "productGUIDs": [ { "surface": "Kitchen_Countertop", "productGUID": "348a14de-c285-4c19-8a82-2f31a4..." } ], "discontinued": false, "hidden": false } ``` ### Response The response from the server will confirm the successful addition of the client package. It typically includes a status message and may provide additional details about the created package, such as its GUID and any other relevant information. #### Expected Response Structure
